body:
That might cause regressions.  See #429 for an example where libuv had to lower the stack size of new thread.

What we could do is set the stack size to 2 MB (4 MB on ppc) if RLIMIT_STACK is ~not~ RLIM_INFINITY because that is what glibc does.  It would make libuv's behavior consistent across libcs.

Happy to code up a PR if there is consensus.

(edit: fixed typo - _is_, not _not is_.)
i believe we expect a stack size of around 1 MB, so getting 2 would be all right for us

issue.title: linux: increase thread stack size with musl libc
issue.body:
musl has tiny default thread stack sizes compared to glibc (80 kB vs.
2048 kB or more) so set an explicit stack size to harmonize between
different libcs.

Fixes: https://github.com/libuv/libuv/issues/1507

issue.title: Segmentation fault upon syntax error
issue.body:
I'm using `grunt-sass` to compile several files across my project. If there are no syntax errors, everything runs smoothly. If I run into a syntax error or any similar error, I encounter a segmentation fault. I've used `node-segfault-handler` to get the following log:

The issue also seems connected to how many files or how many `@import` statements are being processed. If I add two, three, four files with just a few imports, it's still fine. But then I add another file with a lot of imports, and the segfault appears again. If I leave that last file where the segfault was just introduced, and I remove all the others, there's no issue, so it doesn't appear to be connected to particular files.

I've searched for solutions to this issue for a while but I've picked up on few patterns between the failures and none of the other Sass segfault solutions out there have worked. I've tried:

- Downgrading `grunt-sass` to previous versions (which track previous versions of `node-sass`)
- Downgrading `node` to previous versions

body:
We are currently getting random segfault crashes when libuv dlopens a library on `node:14-alpine` on heroku.
My only hint is the stack size, but it seems the stack size issue has been solved here.
Do you have any thoughts?

I am thinking of re-compiling node with `-fstack-check` and `-fstack-protector-all` to try confirm it's still a stack size issue :thinking:
What do the backtraces in gdb look like? Does valgrind print anything that might be relevant?

We have no debugging information yet.

But I can tell that running `ulimit -s` on a docker container running on heroku gives 8192, which seems to be the value returned in https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.x/src/unix/thread.c#L194-L196.

This is so far from 128 times less than the default 2^20 value returned at https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.x/src/unix/thread.c#L205.

So I am wondering what made you choose 8192 as a large enough value here?

> what made you choose 8192 as a large enough value 

I think you're conflating units. :-)

`ulimit -s` reports the stack size in kilobytes, i.e., 8192 means 8 MB. Libuv honors that setting.

That 8192 you see in libuv's source code is the absolute lower bound that libuv accepts and it's in bytes, not kilobytes.
FTR, the node application was actually still using node v10, which [I think] doesn't include the PR's modifications.
